text: Hi again.  I ran my json through JSONLint and it checks out fine but when I try to run it in ember I get an error in the console that there is an unexpected token of a colon.  If I put ‘var = {‘ at the beginning of my file it removes the error but I’m not getting any data either.  I feel like I am so close but missing a step somewhere.  I could show you the files on github but now I have played with them so much they are probably a mess!
Oh but at least I’m not getting any syntax errors anymore.  :stuck_out_tongue:
github link please?
<https://github.com/jenniferpike/development>
hm
so first thing I’m seeing a syntax error on `app/routes/productCategories.js`
missing closing bracket in line 8
<@U0LVBSC67>: after fixing that, the app starts working. Where should I look next?
Yeah I can get the app to run but not load any data at all now.  When you click on ‘our-products’ are you seeing anything on the page (other than what gets stuck from the index page)?
I think all of the bugs I have now are probably related
Also I added you to the master branch so you could see the way I did it originally
(just for a comparison)
ok, I think it doesn’t like that route files are camel-cased?
<@U0LVBSC67>: try renaming them to kebab-case. Eg: `productCategories` to `product-categories`
not 100% sure though
ok let me try that now
but, if you add a `console.log` in `model()`, you can see it doesn’t get called
looks like I am getting ‘findBy is not a function
push to github and I’ll have another look
ok should be there now
right. I’m seeing now
so, when something like this happens, you should have a look at `data` and see if it’s expected to have a `findBy` function
you can have a look by changing that line to read `.then(data => console.log(data));`
if you do that, do you notice what’s wrong?
Looks like it is nested to me and needs an object
yes. Your JSON data is an object, so you probably want to `findBy` one of its properties, not the whole thing
probably `data.productCategories`? Not sure
ok so the good news is i’m not seeing an error in the console now but I’m also not seeing data on the page.  I’ve tried  .then(data => data.productCategories.findBy('categoryTitle'));
after banging my head on the desk for a couple of minutes, I realised something… :simple_smile:
why do you do `findBy` at all?
what do you intend with it?
What what I originally wanted to do was filter by ‘this’

The way it was working before, i could get data on all of the pages but when it was something that needed to be filtered, it only showed the first item in the array and not the respective item to the link clicked.
what do you mean by `this` in that context?
For example if I could do:  {{#link-to "products” productCategory.categoryUrl THIS class="item-grid__link"}}
not entirely sure I follow, but don’t worry. I’ll explain what’s wrong here
you are doing `findBy`, which has two problems
the first one is that it should take a second argument, saying what `productCategory` should be compared to
second: once `findBy` works, it will return a single item, and that will become the model. The template, however, has `each` that implies the model is a list, not a single item
ok that makes sense.  I tried findAll at one point and got a message that it wasn’t a function.
also how would i filter that way?
can any of the filtering be done in the template in the link-to?
re: findings, just return `data.productCategories`, which looks like something that template can deal with
as for filtering, I’m still not sure what you mean by ‘this’. Is it like an id from the path?
eg: `/our-products/:products` would be the bit in `:products`
well yeah an id or the url from the json
ok. So if it was `/our-products/storage`, you would want to only show the `storage` item in `productCategories` in the JSON, right?

the way i originally had it all of the items were listed on the product categories page and when you clicked on one you were brought to the correct page.  You just were not given the information respective to the item you clicked.  Just the information for the very first item in the array
yes exactly
looking at the routes, I see two different routes that affect this: `/our-products` and `/our-products/:products`
I assume the first one would show the list and the second one would show a single one?

yeah i guess it’s confusing.  Basically the goal is Our Products will bring you to a list by category.  Then you click on the category to see a list of products in that category.  When you click on a product you are taken to a product detail page.
in the routes i keep going back and forth on nesting them.  I thought I would get all of the rest of this worked out and then revisit that.
ok, so I think you were trying to do too many things in one route
those are three routes, which you correctly list in router.js
for product-categories.js, focus on showing the list with all of them
at the moment (after removing the findBy) it fails because `product-singlecategories` is not a route
probably should be just `products`, I think
yes i changed that one on my end to products
if i remove the findBy do I need the promise?
wait i take that back, that is for the ajax
correct
incidentally, `findBy` is immediate so it wouldn’t need a promise
ok so product-categories is showing data now
not clicking through to anything though
push?
ok should be up now
ok, so two problems here
(that I can immediately see)
<@U040LNZ6Y|kelvin> has left the channel
in fact check out the console. Any familiar error?
